paragraphs.text: Why Tunisia succeeded where Egypt failed.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: The coincidence couldn't be more striking
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As Tunisians prepare for a run-off in their first full presidential elections, an Egyptian court has declared invalid all remaining murder and corruption charges against former President Hosni Mubarak
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which stemmed from his three decades of misrule and the hundreds killed in the brutal crackdown he launched to preserve it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: denizens of Tunis debate whether interim President Moncef Marzouki or Ben Ali era veteran Beji Caid Essebsi can best move the country forward
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: security forces in Cairo fired on crowds who attempted to enter Tahrir Square, the erstwhile centre of the revolution, to protest the Mubarak decision, killing at least one person while arresting dozens
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The untold thousands of peaceful protesters and activists rotting in Egypt's jails and the cult of personality today surrounding President Abdel Fattah el- Sisi tell the story of how the reluctant decision by Tahrir's revolutionaries to agree to a military-led transition turned out
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In Tunisia, the elements of the state, such as the interior ministry, remain bastions of the ancien regime
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the country has undeniably moved further than any Arab country towards a real and sustainable democracy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This should not surprise anyone familiar with Tunisia's history
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as the country boasts the Arab - indeed, Muslim - world's first modern constitution, from 1861, and has long been among the most cosmopolitan and open in the region
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But the central issue today is precisely how the country built its post-Ben Ali leadership
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Whatever one wants to say about the Islamist Nahda Party, its spiritual and political leader Rachid Ghannoushi re-entered Tunisian politics with a long history of supporting pluralism and democracy
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when it was clear that the party could not govern effectively, it ceded power and agreed to new elections
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: members have engaged in public self-criticism about its failings
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Equally if not more important, Marzouki is one of the Arab world's most respected human rights figures
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: whose Congress for the Republic Party has brought together various opposition tendencies since its creation in 2001
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: His term in office has been far from a sterling success
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it could not have been otherwise, given the Herculean task of building a new governing system on the still functioning body of Ben Ali's mafia state
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But despite political assassinations, flaring religious extremism, and deep- seated economic problems, the country has moved to solidify a new civil and democratic political system
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The contrast with the Egyptian post-revolutionary leadership couldn't be clearer
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There are many structural reasons why Tunisia has progressed politically while Egypt has seemingly returned to its pharaonic roots(as many commentators like to describe its penchant for authoritarian leaders)
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The most prominent are the exponentially greater power of the Egyptian military vis-a-vis its North African counterpart and its far larger, and poorer, population
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But I would argue that the centrality, at least politically, of human rights to the national discourse has been one of the unheralded heroes of the post- revolutionary period
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Just compare Tunisia and its president with the situation in Egypt
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Abdel Basset Hassan, head of the Arab Institute for Human Rights in Tunis and a long-time resident of Cairo, explained to me when we met in September, human rights are clearly being institutionalised to a strong degree
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The problem is that human rights is a frail political discourse
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Whether in the most "advanced" democracies like the United States and UK, or developing countries like Egypt and Tunisia, it's easily swept aside by appeals to core national and/or religious identities and the creation of threats
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: whose defeat inevitably requires watering down the protections afforded to all citizens
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: More broadly, human rights exists in a contradictory political framework
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In most societies they both require revolutionary change to be fully implemented and yet are routinely violated in revolutionary situations where one form of power is, more or less violently, overpowering and superseding another
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As revolutions from Iran to Cuba have shown, its all too easy for revolutions fought in the name of human rights, justice and dignity to themselves produce violent and repressive systems
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What's
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: more
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: human rights is intimately tied to a notion of individual personhood that can all too easily be hijacked to a kind of market fundamentalist liberalism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: in which broad political freedom masks incredibly deep and destruction inequalities, exploitation, and repression - whether of colonised peoples "outremer" or of working classes at home
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: for anyone who's experienced the Egyptian and Tunisian revolutions in action, the power and importance of human rights is undeniable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It remains one of the most radical concepts of the modern era; first, because it demands recognising others as inherently equal to oneself regardless of their differences- ethnic, racial, gender, religion, class, or nation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Second
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they demand strict limitation on state power
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which is inherently and, unless checked, normatively abusive of citizens
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And this is where the situation in Tunisia remains perilous despite the smooth parliamentary and presidential elections of the last two months
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Marzouki's Congress for the Republic party represents a poorer and more traditional (and southern) component of Tunisian society
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Essebsi's Nida Tounes Party is not merely tied to the old regime, but to the international financial interests to which it was beholden
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Indeed
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the main threat in Tunisia today, in this regard, is not a religious- secular divide but left-neoliberal, with the two powerful parties working together to suppress all opposition to once again making Tunisia the Arab world's "poster child" for a "broken down" neoliberal reform model
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which has always produced- and masked - the desperate inequalities that led to the revolution against Ben Ali in the first place
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For decades, neoliberalism has produced the same results most everywhere it has been implemented: aggregate growth that mask growing inequality, increasing corruption, crime, environmental degradation and repression
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The only check on such policies would be a strong and united left (the opposite of the present situation, by some accounts) centred broadly on labour rights, a fair distribution of wealth and resources and fighting against the corruption that fatally weakened the previous state
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But one of the signature strengths of neoliberal ideologies, from Kansas to Cairo, is precisely how efficiently they motivate people to support leaders and policies that are manifestly against their economic interests
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A Nida Tounes-Nahda alignment would provide a powerful ideological and political cover for retrenching the policies that brought Tunisia to the brink of revolution
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On the other hand
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: , there are more positive countervailing forces at work in Tunis that are cause for long-term hope
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This process is exemplified by the establishment of Dar Essaida, or Saida House, a human rights centre located in and emerging from the local community in one of Tunis' poorest quarters
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As Hassan explained, encouraging the poor and working class to(re) define the political and cultural discourses of human rights in ways that reflect their struggles and desires marks an important moment in the evolution of human rights practice
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "It's about implementing a complete vision, and as important, getting it out to the widest public," Hassan declared
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "This is the only way to strengthen advances in areas such as women's rights or constitutional reforms
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the culture is harder to change
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you can't just root out all the networks of the former mafia state in one year, or even ten
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It's a long process
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it's not fruitful to use the angle of 'better or worse' to judge it now."
paragraphs.label: testimony
